3:53:21
question everyone's asking is simple. Which AI is actually better? GPT5 just dropped. Claude Opus 4.1 is making waves
3:53:28
and Gemini 2.5 Pro claims to be the smartest yet. But here's the thing. Everyone talks about these AE is. Nobody
3:53:36
actually tests them properly. So I did what nobody else would do. I put them through real challenges, not simple
3:53:42
questions, not basic tasks, real work that matters. What I found will change how you think about AI forever. Let me
3:53:49
start with the first test. I asked all three A's to build a game called Pixel Ninja Dash. The goal was simple. Create
3:53:55
a single page app where you dash and jump across rooftops while slicing enemy robots. Sounds easy, right? Wrong.
3:54:03
Here's what happened. Gemini finished first. The UI looked good, but the game was so hard to play, I wanted to throw
3:54:10
my computer out the window. GPT5 came second. Again, nice UI, but just like
3:54:15

3:54:21
but here's the twist. The game was actually fun to play. Easy controls, nice night city lights, cute background.
3:54:27
While the other two made games that looked good but felt terrible, Claude made something you'd actually want to play. This tells us something important.
3:54:34
Speed doesn't always win. Pretty doesn't always work. Sometimes the AI that takes longer makes something better. But wait,
3:54:40
it gets more interesting. Test two was Candy Match Blast. Match three candies score points. Beat the clock. Standard
3:54:47
match three game that everyone knows. Gemini finished first again, but there was an error. The game didn't work. So,
3:54:53
while I waited for Gemini to fix it, Claude finished. And holy cow, instead of regular candy graphics, Claude used
3:55:00
emojis, chocolates, candies, sweets. It looked completely different from what the others made. GPT5 finished next. The
3:55:08
design was like painted balls. Pretty and polished. It worked well. Finally, Gemini fixed its error and came last.
3:55:15
When it finally worked, I wasn't impressed. The design was boring compared to the others. Claude won this round. Not because it was fastest,
3:55:21
because it was creative. It fought outside the box. It made something unique while the others played it safe.
3:55:26
This is where most people get AI wrong. They think faster means better. They think first place means best. But what
3:55:33
actually matters is results. What matters is whether the thing you ask for
3:55:38
actually works the way you need it to. Test three was jungle run adventure. Run
3:55:44
and jump across jungle platforms. Collect bananas. Avoid traps. Infinite
3:55:49

3:55:56

3:56:01
good, but there were no bananas, no collectibles, just a monkey running. I gave it another chance. The second
3:56:07
version didn't work at all. Gemini came next. It worked most of the time, but sometimes the space bar didn't respond.
3:56:13

3:56:18
bananas. GPT5 came last. The game crashed completely three times. It just
3:56:24
couldn't handle this challenge at all. This test showed me something crucial. When AIs fail, they fail differently.
3:56:30
Some fail fast and recover. Some fail slow but work eventually. Some just keep
3:56:35
failing no matter what you do. But here's what's really happening behind the scenes. Each AI has different
3:56:40

Transitions are effects that the audience will see when you advance from one
3:25:40
slide to another during a presentation.
3:25:46
Animations, on the other hand, happen on the slide.
3:25:52
We're gonna start with transitions. So typically, I will use one transition The same exact transition for all
3:26:02
of the slides in my presentation, just to keep it very spare.
3:26:08
Also, it helps to keep the audience's attention.
3:26:13
Imagine you had 50 slides and you used different transitions between them, or a
3:26:20
mix of different transitions between them. At some point, your audience is going to start thinking, I wonder
3:26:28
what cool thing is going to happen. when he or she advances to the next slide instead of paying attention
3:26:36
to the content of your presentation. So I'm just going to use one transition for all slides.
3:26:43

---



In today's video, I'm going to be giving
0:01
you a Google Classroom tutorial for
0:03
beginners. If you find this video
0:05
useful, please be sure to like and
0:06
subscribe, and let's get right into it.
0:08
Let's begin by accessing Google
0:10
Classroom. To start, open your preferred
0:12
web browser and go to the Google
0:14
Classroom homepage. If you haven't used
0:15
Google Classroom before, you'll
0:17
recognize it by its clean and intuitive
0:19
interface, which is designed to make
0:21
managing classes simple and
0:22
straightforward. Once you're on the
0:24
homepage, the next step is to sign into
0:26
your account. Look to the top right
0:28
corner of the page and you'll spot the
0:30
sign in button. Click on it and you'll
0:32
be prompted to enter your Google account
0:34
credentials. If you're a student, make
0:36
sure you're using the email address
0:37
provided by your school to ensure you
0:39
have access to all your classes and
0:40
materials. After successfully logging
0:42
in, you'll be greeted by the home tab,
0:44

Introduction
0:11
My name is Elissa Smith. Now this course is designed for anyone who is looking to maximize
0:17
the use of their Gmail account. Not only are we gonna show you how to create a Gmail account and also use it,
0:25
filter it, sort it, even label your Gmail. But we're also going to spend some time showing you other great features
0:31
that come with a Gmail account, like the chat feature, and your Google Calendar, and also your Google Contacts.
0:38
So please join us on this journey while we really learn to maximize your experience with Google Gmail.
Creating a Gmail Account
0:47
Hi everyone. In this lesson I wanna show you how to create your own Gmail account. So I'm gonna be using, uh, Google Chrome for this session because of course
0:56
that's what Gmail would like us to do. So I'm gonna come in and actually search for my Google site to
1:04
perform a search to find Gmail. Now that I'm at the Google search site, I can go ahead and come right
1:09
here and do a search for Gmail. This is going to either log me into an existing Gmail account, or it's going
1:16
to give me an option to actually go in and create a Gmail account of my own notice here in the middle, I can create a personal Gmail account, or I can
1:25
attribute a Gmail account to work also. Same options in the top right now. A little bit of background on what Gmail is, it's Google's free
1:33
web-based email hosting service. It was actually launched in 2004, invitation only, and
1:38
then made public in 2009. The thing you need to understand is that when you sign up for a Gmail account,
1:44
you're also getting a Google account, which is awesome because it gives you access to Google's online services like Google Docs, sheets, slides.
1:54
Calendar, Google meets along with additional tools. Now, a Google account also can sometimes be attributed to
2:01
what's called Google Workspace. Google Workspace is actually an online productivity and collaboration application
2:08
suite that Google also created. It actually started back in 2006. It was rebranded to the G Suite in 2016, and now in October
2:18
of 2020, it's officially been called the Google Workspace. This course is gonna focus, of course, on Gmail, but just know that sometimes
2:26
when you have Gmail, you may also have access to the Google Workspace, which gives you even more tools, especially if you're using Gmail as a tool for work.
2:35
For email at work. Now, what I'm gonna do is come right here to create account, and it's going to take
2:41
me to where I need to provide a name. This won't necessarily be my Gmail name because remember, there are
2:48
2 billion Gmail users, so many of these names have been used up. Notice it makes suggestions for you.
2:56
What I would suggest here is continue trying different combinations until
3:01
you find one that will work, and sometimes it takes a few tries. Once you do, you'll see that there's no red involved down here.
3:10
You need to provide a password. Remember that these passwords are going to be case sensitive and they are
3:17
encrypted, so don't lose your password. The next screen is gonna ask you for information for a recovery email, your
3:25
birthday, your gender, and after that your Gmail account's going to be created.
3:30
Stay with me and come to the next lesson so we can actually start learning to use our email.
Logging In and Navigating
3:39
Hi everyone. We're ready to log into my Gmail account. So what I'm gonna do is come into my Chrome browser, type
3:46
in Gmail, up in my URL bar. This will take you to your login screen for your Gmail account.
3:53
Now that the account's been created, I can get into it. So I'm gonna come here to the top right hand corner, click on sign
3:59
in, and then of course I'll type in my Gmail address that I created.
4:06
And then my password. Remember, the passwords are encrypted, they're case sensitive, and don't give
4:12
them out to anyone because you don't want them to have access to your Gmail. Once I'm in my Gmail account.
4:20
Let's take a minute and look at how easy it is to navigate in this area. So a couple of important features in the Gmail interface on the top left hand
4:29
side, below the back button, and the U R L bar of whatever browser you're using.
4:34
Because remember, you can use Gmail with just about any browser. So Edge, Firefox, Chrome, safari.
4:41
We're using Chrome because of course this is a Google tool, but right here you're gonna see that it shows me I'm in Gmail.

Guided Learning (scaffolded learning on long PDFs)
18:27
All right, guided learning is obviously really great if you're studying or
18:32
trying to learn something on the side, but it's also really useful if you, like
18:38
me, work in corporate, which I know a lot of you watching are doing. So, let's
18:43
say that you get sent a corporate document, a long PDF containing a lot of
18:49
information that you need to learn by heart for a presentation or a Q&A, or let's just say that you want to absorb
18:55
or digest that content with more ease and without having to spend as much time
19:00
doing it. What you can then do is take that report. Let's say that we got sent
19:05
this state of AI report that we looked at earlier in the video. You drop that
19:11
in here and then you turn on guided learning under tools and then you can
19:16
just say I need to quickly understand the key concepts of this report.
19:24
Where do I start? All right. So what you can see that Gemini is doing here is it says let's explore the report together.
19:32
The central theme here is a massive gap between adoption and scaling. was giving you a short introduction paragraph here
19:37
and then this is key to help you get a handle of the key concepts. Where should you where would you like to start and
19:43
you can now pick one of the three main areas of the report that you can dig further into. Now the reason why I think
19:51
this is pretty interesting is because a common but very strong presentation
19:56
technique that is especially useful when discussing complex topics is something called scaffolded learning. And the core
20:03
principle is fairly simple and you can actually see it being applied here. The idea is that you start with a very
20:10
simple approach. Allow the audience to feel like they're following you as you gradually increase complexity. And you
20:17
can leverage the same concept in Gemini. If you say like I did here, where do I
20:23
start? Or you can also say like explain this like I'm five, the famous movie quote, you would effectively be
20:29
triggering the scaffolded learning. And at the same time, if you want a specific
20:35
detail in the report, you can of course go straight into that as well. It's not by any mean, shape, or form fine-tuned
20:42
to always use scaffolded learning, but rather it will adapt accordingly if you
20:47
want something specific out of a report. So, let's say that we were to pick one of these. Let's say the rise of the AI
20:54
agents. Let's go with 2. Then you will see that Gemini keeps unfolding further
20:59
information and dive deeper into more and more complexity as you decide where
21:05
you want to delve deeper and it will always prompt you with a next step. So you can see here to help you get a
21:11
better grip on this which aspect would you like to explore next and it gives you the three options. So you kind of
21:16
just need to tag along here and Gemini will basically do the hard work for you. And by the way, you don't have to use a
21:23
report like I did. That's just a pretty good corporate use case for those of you that are interested in that. You could
21:29
basically ask whatever in the chat, turn on guided learning, and Gemini will start training you on that topic.

The visual layout feature transforms standard text into rich magazine style
21:46
pages with images, cards, and interactive widgets as opposed to kind of giving you the standard wall of text
21:53
that we always get in the chat. Common use cases would be exploring complex topics or more casual things like travel
21:59
planning, shopping, comparison, or recipes. Let's say that you wanted to pick a more complex topic like learning

how large language models work. All you would need to do is go into tools again,

models LLM work to a nontechnical

audience using a visual guide. Now we fire that away. All right, here we go.
22:36
Large language models, a word prediction machine. So you can see kind of these uh interactive uh pictures that are
22:43
toggling through. So it says here that imagine an LLM as a highly sophisticated autocomplete function.
22:51
Dude, you're not selling yourself very well, are you? It doesn't truly understand the way humans does, but it
22:58
analyzed patterns in billions of pages of text. For those of you that don't know, the way LLMs basically work is
23:05
that it's a statistical model that guesses the next word in the sequence. And then it basically further down here
23:11
says that there are three core steps of an LLM. So step one is training, step two is the tokenization, and step three
23:16
is the prediction. And because I have fat fingers, I decided to click on step one. And it started compiling the next
23:25
steps, which is fine. I plan to show you that later. But let's just jump back
23:31
here for a second. The important part here is that you get a structured output
23:36
telling you how LLMs work. Now, this could of course have come in a chat as well, but this is a little bit more easy
23:44
and fun to digest than a wall of text. And what it always does is give you a
23:51
set of suggestions on what to explore further. So here it suggested bias and
23:56
ethics, retrieval, augmented generation, which you probably heard me harp about a couple of times if you are not a
24:02
first-time listener, etc. And if you were to click any of these, it would then build out the next response. Now
24:08
what I did is I clicked step one up here. So the training and now it has
24:13
compiled the next element of this visual layout which is around training. And you
24:18
can see here that it outlines three phases of LLM training, which is data cleaning, then pre-training, and lastly
24:24
fine-tuning. So the key thing to take away here is that if you prefer this
24:29
type of output when you are chatting with Gemini, then you can just turn on visual layout and you'll get it in this
24:36
format instead.
Scheduled Actions: weekly AI update automation
24:43
scheduled actions works very similar to the way chatbt does it in case you have
24:48
tried it over there. So let's just jump straight into it. In the chat all you
24:53
need to do is basically tell Gemini to set it up for you. So let's for example
24:59
say create a weekly scheduled action
25:05
every Monday at CT. send me a summary of
25:11
the latest AI updates from past week. And that's it. You just fire it away and
25:19
Gemini will set that up for you. And there we go. So basically what's going to happen now is that every Monday at
25:26
8:00 my time, it will create a summary for me based on the latest news in the
25:32
AI space and give me a notification that that has happened. So if you for example
25:38
have the app downloaded on your phone then it's going to give you a notification and you will also see it in
25:44
the left hand side here. You can actually see one of my um one of my other scheduled tasks which fired off
25:51
earlier today and you can of course always come back into this chat and turn it off. You can edit it here as well.
25:58
But it will of course be quite painful to try and find a very old chat if you
26:05
for example have had a scheduled action laying around for a while. So there's a better way of doing that which is to go
26:12
down to the settings and then there is a tab here called scheduled actions. So
26:17
you just go in there and you will see all of your actions listed. And from
26:22
here you can either toggle them on and off like this. You can go in and adjust
26:27
the details of it. And of course, if you just want to take it out completely, you have the delete button down here.
Prompt engineering (how to get better output)
26:39
All right, this wouldn't be a tutorial if we didn't talk prompting best practices. So, let's just quickly cover
26:44
that off. For Gemini 3 Pro, which I recommend you to use instead of the fast
26:50
model, it's fairly simple. It's a reasoning model meaning that you should treat it more as a kind of senior
26:56
colleague rather than a junior colleague which your standard chat models like chat GP5 would be considered as. That
27:03
means that you need to focus less on how it executes a task and focus more on what it should achieve. Now Google are
27:10
outlining three points that are important to be aware of when you're using Gemini 3 Pro. So the first is to
27:17
be concise in your input prompts. So it says Gemini 3 responds best to direct
27:22
clear instructions. It may overanalyze verbose or overly complex prompt engineering techniques used for odal
27:28
models. And this is very important to be aware of because with normal chat
27:34
models, the general rule of thumb is the more context the better. But that actually confuses a reasoning model.
27:41
Keep it short and to the point. The second thing is output verbosity. The
27:46
key takeaway here is that Gemini 3 is by default less verbose and prefers providing direct efficient answers. And
27:53
that basically means that if you want it to be more elaborative around the topic, you need to tell it to do so. So it
27:59
basically says here, if your use case requires a more conversational or chatty persona, you must explicitly steer the
28:05
model in the prompt. Eg explain this as a friendly talkative assistant. Now, if you're like me and prefer the model to
28:11
get to the point, then it's just good to know that this is the way it works. But you don't actually need to do anything about it. In fact, you can actually
28:18
prompt it to be even more direct if you prefer that. I tend to do that, by the way. And the last thing to be aware of
28:24
here is around the context management. So basically, the key takeaway here is that when you're working with a large
28:30
data set, you should place your specific instruction or question at the end of the prompt after the data context. And
28:38
that is typically very different to how we have looked at prompt engineering for all the previous models where the task
28:46
typically comes first or second if you have a persona but it's basically at the
28:52
top of your prompt. And here it's essentially telling you to put it at the bottom and instead focus on the context
28:58
management. But all in all the key takeaway here is you don't need to
29:04
overcontextualize when working with Gemini 3. It's really less is more.
Key settings that actually matter
29:12
Now, the last thing I want to leave you with is some important settings to be aware of. So, the settings you'll find
29:17
down here. And the first one, and probably one of the most important ones, is your baseline instructions for
29:24

29:30
